title: Abstract: Scope and Sequence of Data Science Course
body: This document outlines the scope and sequence of a data science course, divided into four units. Unit 1 introduces the concept of data, its ubiquity, and the basics of descriptive statistics using RStudio, covering data representation, measures of center and spread, and basic plotting. Unit 2 deepens analytical tools by introducing probability, simulations, and linear models, emphasizing computational thinking and model evaluation. Unit 3 focuses on data collection methods, including designed experiments, observational studies, surveys, and Participatory Sensing, along with data scraping and handling different data formats. Unit 4 builds on modeling skills, teaching least squares regression, prediction evaluation, algorithmic approaches, and culminates in a complete modeling experience where students apply learned concepts to analyze data, design campaigns, and create various models like CART. Throughout the course, students will develop skills in data analysis, statistical reasoning, computational thinking, and critically evaluating data-based reports, aligning with Common Core State Standards for Mathematics (CCSS-M) and Standards for Mathematical Practice (SMPs).

title: Unit 1: Introduction to Data and Descriptive Statistics
body: Unit 1 introduces the fundamental concept of data, emphasizing that data encompasses much more than just spreadsheets, including images, text, and GPS coordinates. It highlights the increasing data-centric nature of the modern world and how data is generated and used for various purposes like political forecasting, marketing, and personalized recommendations. The unit contrasts traditional statistics' focus on sampling with the broader data landscape. Students will learn to analyze and evaluate data products (charts, graphs, statistics) critically, considering data collection methods, creator bias, and representation choices. Key statistical techniques covered include descriptive statistics, constructing multiple data views, and using RStudio for graphical displays (histograms, scatterplots) and measures of center and spread. This unit aligns with CCSS-M standards S-ID 1, S-ID 2, S-ID 3, S-ID 5, S-ID 6, and S-IC 6, as well as SMPs 3 and 5. Learning outcomes include identifying personal data traces, understanding data structures, evaluating media reports, interpreting plots, calculating probabilities, and using RStudio for basic data tasks.

title: Unit 1: Data Structures and RStudio Basics
body: In Unit 1, students learn that data is structured, with rows and columns representing fundamental data structures. They will begin using the computational tool R through the RStudio interface. This includes loading data into RStudio, creating basic plots such as histograms and scatterplots, and constructing frequency tables. The unit emphasizes understanding how data is collected and represented, motivating the critical evaluation of data products. Students will gain practical skills in RStudio to visualize data distributions and summarize categorical data. This foundational unit prepares students to analyze and interpret various forms of data encountered throughout the course, aligning with the goal of making sense of ubiquitous data types and developing critical thinking skills related to data analysis and representation.

title: Unit 1: Focus Statistics Standards (CCSS-M)
body: Unit 1 focuses on several key statistics standards from the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics (CCSS-M). Specifically, students will address S-ID 1 (Represent data with plots on the real number line, including dotplots, histograms, and boxplots), S-ID 2 (Use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data distribution to compare center and spread of data sets), S-ID 3 (Interpret differences in shape, center, and spread, considering outliers), S-ID 5 (Summarize categorical data using two-way frequency tables and interpret relative frequencies), and S-ID 6 (Represent data on a scatterplot for two quantitative variables and describe their relationship). Additionally, S-IC 6 (Evaluate reports based on data) is a recurring standard woven throughout the course. These standards provide the mathematical foundation for understanding and analyzing data in Unit 1.

title: Unit 1: Focus Mathematical Practices
body: The mathematical practices emphasized in Unit 1 are crucial for developing a robust understanding of data science. SMP-3, 'Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others,' is central to evaluating data reports and understanding how data products are constructed. Students will learn to question the evidence, consider perspectives, and analyze the processes behind data representation. SMP-5, 'Use appropriate tools strategically,' is addressed through the introduction and use of RStudio. Students will learn to select and effectively utilize computational tools for data analysis, visualization, and interpretation. These practices equip students not only with technical skills but also with the critical thinking and reasoning abilities necessary for a data-literate individual.

title: Unit 1: Learning Outcomes
body: Upon completion of Unit 1, students will possess a foundational understanding of data science concepts and practical skills. Key learning outcomes include: identifying personal data generation ('data traces'); recognizing rows and columns as data structures; explaining potential reasons for variable relationships; constructing and interpreting frequency tables; critically reading and evaluating media reports based on data; interpreting various plots by identifying their type, axes, trends, and confounding factors; calculating conditional and marginal probabilities from frequency tables; providing real-world explanations for probability concepts using critical thinking; communicating data evaluations effectively; loading data into RStudio; creating basic plots in RStudio; and creating frequency tables in RStudio. These outcomes prepare students for more advanced topics in subsequent units.

title: Unit 2: Probability, Simulations, and Linear Models
body: Unit 2 builds upon the foundational reasoning skills from Unit 1 by introducing more precise analytical tools and technical vocabulary. A core concept is the formal introduction of probability as a method to understand when observed data patterns might be coincidental rather than significant. Unlike traditional courses that focus on abstract mathematical probability, this unit uses simulations with pseudo-random number generators to build enduring understanding, concurrently developing computational thinking through basic programming structures. The unit also foregrounds the use of models, introducing linear models as a common form in introductory statistics. These models will serve as a basis for learning more complex modeling techniques, including smoothing and tree-based models, utilizing computer technology. This unit aligns with CCSS-M standards S-ID 2, S-ID 3, S-ID 4, S-IC 2, S-IC 6, S-CP 2, and S-CP 9, and SMPs 4 and 5.

title: Unit 2: Advanced Descriptive Statistics and Distributions
body: In Unit 2, students deepen their understanding of descriptive statistics by incorporating measures of spread like the interquartile range (IQR) and standard deviation, alongside measures of center (median, mean). They will learn to use these statistics to compare data sets, considering the shape of distributions and the impact of outliers (S-ID 2, S-ID 3). A significant focus is placed on the normal distribution (S-ID 4), where students will learn to fit data to it, estimate population percentages, and understand its limitations. This involves using tools like calculators and spreadsheets to estimate areas under the normal curve. The unit also introduces the concept of simulations (S-IC 2) to determine if a data-generating process is consistent with observed results, providing a practical approach to statistical inference.

title: Unit 2: Computational Skills and Data Merging
body: Unit 2 enhances students' computational abilities by introducing fundamental programming structures in RStudio, specifically `for()` loops and `apply()` functions. Students will learn to create their own functions, promoting modularity and efficiency in coding. Data manipulation skills are expanded to include merging data by columns and rows, with an emphasis on verifying the success of these operations. These programming and data handling techniques are essential for implementing simulations, building models, and managing more complex datasets encountered in data science. The focus on `for()` loops and `apply()` functions supports the development of computational thinking, a key aspect of the unit's learning objectives.

title: Unit 2: Learning Outcomes for Probability and Modeling
body: Upon completion of Unit 2, students will be able to perform advanced statistical analyses and apply modeling concepts. They will create boxplots by calculating the five-number summary, fences, and identifying outliers. They will explain the meaning of 'standard deviation' in context and articulate why measures of central tendency and spread are appropriate or not for given data. Students will use permutations to solve problems and interpret normal curves/distributions, understanding their origins and applicability. Key outcomes include simulating normal distributions and other models, comparing simulated results with real data, and determining model consistency. Furthermore, students will master merging data frames, writing `for()` loops and `apply()` functions in RStudio, and creating their own functions.

title: Unit 3: Data Collection Methods and Participatory Sensing
body: Unit 3 delves into various data collection methodologies, contrasting traditional approaches like designed experiments, observational studies, and surveys with the more modern concept of Participatory Sensing. Students will learn about sampling error and bias, which can affect the analysis of survey data. Participatory Sensing is presented as a distinct method utilizing sensors and emphasizing community involvement in data collection within their lived environments. The role of 'triggers' in this process is explored, noting that responses may vary. The unit also addresses the diversity of online data forms and the necessity for different representation styles, enhancing computing skills by learning about modern data structures and 'scraping' data from XML formats. This unit supports CCSS-M standards S-IC 1, S-IC 3, and S-IC 6, and SMPs 1, 4, and 8.

title: Unit 3: Statistical Inference Foundations
body: Unit 3 lays the groundwork for statistical inference by defining statistics as a process for making inferences about population parameters from sample data (S-IC 1). Students will compare and contrast key concepts: population versus sample, and parameter versus statistic. They will learn to recognize the purposes and differences among sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies, understanding how randomization plays a role in each (S-IC 3). The unit also revisits measures of central tendency and spread, discussing situations where specific measures are more appropriate than others, and delves deeper into interpreting boxplots, considering the relationship between sample size and population parameters. The ability to identify reports utilizing specific data structures (census, survey, observational study, randomized experiment) is a key outcome.

title: Unit 3: Data Scraping and RStudio Applications
body: In Unit 3, students enhance their computing skills by learning to handle modern data structures and perform data scraping, specifically focusing on extracting data from XML formats. This involves working with HTML and XML, essential skills for acquiring data from the web. In RStudio, students will apply these concepts by learning to re-randomize data, a technique valuable for analysis and understanding uncertainty. They will also compute measures of central tendency and spread, reinforcing their understanding of descriptive statistics in a practical, computational context. This unit bridges the gap between theoretical data collection methods and their practical implementation using computational tools.

title: Unit 3: Learning Outcomes for Data Collection and Analysis
body: Upon completion of Unit 3, students will have a comprehensive understanding of data collection and initial analysis techniques. They will be able to define 'statistics' in their own words, articulate the differences between population/sample and parameter/statistic, and explain various data structures and their implications for inference. Students will gain proficiency in reading and interpreting boxplots concerning sample size and population parameters, and identify different study designs in reports. Key practical skills include performing data scraping, utilizing HTML and XML formats, re-randomizing data in RStudio, and computing measures of central tendency and spread using RStudio. They will also be able to design and execute their own Participatory Sensing Campaigns.

title: Unit 4: Regression, Prediction, and Modeling Experience
body: Unit 4 focuses on developing advanced modeling skills, starting with fitting and interpreting least squares regression lines and using them for prediction. Students will learn to evaluate the success of these predictions and compare the predictive accuracy of different models. Algorithmic approaches to regression are introduced, strengthening students' algorithmic thinking by explaining how these methods enable accurate predictions. The unit culminates in a complete modeling experience where students integrate skills and concepts from previous units. This experience emphasizes metacognition, encouraging students to reflect on their modeling process, ask questions, and recognize its iterative nature. This unit addresses CCSS-M standards S-IC 2, S-ID 6 (a, b, c), S-ID 7, S-ID 8, and S-IC 6, along with SMPs 2, 4, and 7.

title: Unit 4: Linear Models and Model Evaluation
body: In Unit 4, students will learn to describe the fit of a linear model to data, providing real-world explanations for why a model might fit or not fit. They will interpret the slope and intercept of a linear model in context (S-ID 7). The computation and interpretation of the correlation coefficient using RStudio are covered (S-ID 8). Students will learn to determine if an observed trend is statistically significant or could be due to randomness, using critical thinking to assess the plausibility of trends. The unit involves fitting regression lines and extracting key model components like the slope, intercept, correlation coefficient, coefficient of determination, and residuals using RStudio. Students will also explore the impact of constants on predictor variables in linear models.

title: Unit 4: Advanced Modeling and Computational Tools
body: Unit 4 extends students' modeling capabilities beyond linear regression. They will learn to use RStudio to compute permutations and combinations, further strengthening their understanding of probability and inference. A significant component is the introduction to Classification and Regression Tree (CART) models, providing a foundation for understanding non-linear relationships in data. Students will also gain an understanding of non-linear models in general. The practical application of these skills includes designing and executing their own Participatory Sensing Campaigns, demonstrating their ability to apply learned concepts to real-world data collection and analysis challenges. The unit emphasizes the use of RStudio for various computational tasks, including prediction and model building.

title: Unit 4: Learning Outcomes for Predictive Modeling
body: Upon completion of Unit 4, students will be adept at building and evaluating statistical models. They will be able to describe the quality of a linear model's fit, interpret its components (slope, intercept, correlation coefficient) in context, and use RStudio to extract these statistics and analyze residuals. Students will be able to predict response variables given predictor variables using their models and understand the effects of transformations on models. They will learn to distinguish between real trends and random variation. Practical outcomes include fitting regression lines, using RStudio for predictive modeling, understanding non-linear models, creating CART models, and computing permutations/combinations. A key achievement is the ability to design and execute Participatory Sensing Campaigns and communicate model evaluations effectively.
